title: How did they make snooker balls in the 19th century? - Quora

response.answer_text: With a lathe. If you take a large 'washer' for example, with a drilled round hole in it (and since it IS drilled- on the lathe, then it is a precise round hole), and place that washer on what you is approximately round (wood, stone, plastic, or ivory) piece you are turning on a lathe, then it will impart a sphere EVERY TIME.  That is how you turn a sphere without special tools.Frequently, rubbing graphite (pencil led, or rouge for stone) on the cutting disk is enough, as it shows the 'high spots, which you can remove with emory cloth (sand paper).  Ends are cut-off, and 'clamping' (by pressure) can be accomplished in the final turning, to polish of the former 'ends' of the turning. Lastly, a very precise hard sphere (say: quartz), can be used to fine tune the 'washer', and that master 'washer' can be used to 'fine polish' the finished sphere.  Sphere 'holders' (clamps a sphere from the tailstock and drive 'chuck').
